title: New Orleans
content:
email I sent my people, I live in FL and hurricane katrina could affect us some

*****

sorry to tell you...

...but New Orleans is going to be screwed. It could be submerged with about 20-30 feet of water, lots of old buildings and near coast will be destroyed completely, lots of people could die, and also, they are saying that coffins will start floating around with sewage, toxic substances and building debris to create a mass of deadly bacteria in the water and contaminate the whole city. don't act surprised when 100's of years of history is lost, along with one of the oldest cities in the country and tons of homes. get ready to be in shock.

*****

I hope nobody on here lives in New Orleans, because their home could be destroyed. If you are there, NOW, get in the Super Dome or outta there. It can supposedly resist 200mph winds but who knows about feets of water.

This is just random articles for N.O.:

[url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/2250544938]www.allheadlinenews.com/a...2250544938[/url]

title: Re: New Orleans
content:
I saw some footage of the destruction caused in New Orleans on the news last night. I feel very sorry for the people who've lost homes/ property/ anything because of hurricane katrina. All that stuff you've listed sounds quite bad (obviously coffins floating around with the sewage is not good). I hope it doesn't get to that.--------------

content: I heard something about this from the radio in bus. Doesn't sound promising at all. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]  Hopefully you get through it ok.[url=http://www.keengrid.net/]keengrid.net[/url]

title: back
content:
I'm extremely lucky this time. I lost power at 3-4 AM and now it's back at 5 PM. Usually during these hurricanes I'm the last to get power back.

I was listening to the situation. Two holes in the super dome, looked at them on the TV, they're not too bad. Lots of people in New Orleans called 9-11, approx. 5 per minute. I heard the figure that 150 people with cell phones called on their roof. Others probably weren't so lucky, lots got "out" of the city.

I also heard EARLY on that some old buildings were destroyed.

There's no footage of the part that flooded, that I can see right now

Oh wait here's some

Yeah the water is very deep. They're saying damage by the storm as a whole could total $16 billion, but I heard that early on. French Quarter has been messed up.

Katrina moved to the east just before impact, it's the only thing that saved New Orleans from total devastation. Still really bad though.

content:

title: Re: back
content:
The floodwaters continue to rise. There's no rainfall but the lake is pouring water through the broken levee into New Orleans. People who are trapped tonight might not be able to get help in time. The crews aren't going during the night because there is a lot of broken power and gas lines in the water making swimming or rescuing hazardous.

Starting with a video sent to CNN this morning, there's been a lot of reports of looting in New Orleans.[center][img]http://members.cox.net/aborlan/sig/sigpng.png[/img]

title: New Orleans
content:
It is very sad to see such suffering.

Some people think the U.S. isn't ready for a natural desaster any more, and some question its ability to avoid a terrorist attack. It is very sad.

What I've noticed is how the media keeps talking about how it is okay to loot, in order to stay alive...

Do you eat Nike Shoes, or Plasma TVs?

Think about it.

And the fact that people are shooting people just for the heck of it. Rescue workers bringing in food, and clean water are being shot, and killed...

It is becoming very chaotic...

Will New Orleans ever bounce back?

Just a little food for though.

-- NAJAWA --

title: Re: New Orleans
content:
"Do you eat Nike Shoes, or Plasma TVs?"
Yeah.

I haven't followed any news about it but judging by this topic it seems chaotic. I haven't thought at all that USA is ready for terrorist attacks or stuff, that was proven several years ago already -- they're not.[url=http://www.keengrid.net/]keengrid.net[/url]

title: Geting a bit better
content:
It is getting better, though; security is getting tighter, buildings are getting 5 times the fire code regualtions (5 times the fire proofing), but some still wonder.

*Edited*

You should watch an american news channel like CNN (Cable News Network); some now have 24 hour new coverage. It is amazing to see all who are helping. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

-- NAJAWA --

LL: Hello Djas, Yes I'm here in the big N.O., and even though I have come here with a full euntourage of cameramen, vehicles and snacks, all I'm going to do is look at poor people and lament about how pitiful they look.

Poor Black Guy: Can I have some of that sandwich?

title: New Orleans
content:
*Looks at LL's Avatar*

Hmm... Balck avatar for someone claiming to balance Black looters, and giving the impression that she's white. Hmm...

I am not a racist person, and have a very good friend who's black, they are mostly very good people (Though there are bad people in every race). I am (what people call) white, though, I don't call myself that; I am white when I'm dead. Right now... I'm alive.

LL, you shouldn't catigorize people like that. Even though it may be true, it sends the wrong message.

Beside from my other friend, I know a really nice person (who also happens to be black): [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-lindsey.gif[/img]

Now lets get back on topic: We were talking about the state of N.O., but some of us (Including me, I'm afraid), have gone a little off topic.

*Pulls everyone back on topic*
*Has a little trouble trying to stop LL from looting*
*Succedes* (With the aid of my horrific spelling)

Ah... Better.

-- NAJAWA --
